review_content: La La Land is such a happy, sweet-natured movie - something to give you a Vitamin D boost of sunshine.
Damien Chazelle's La La Land is a wildly ambitious widescreen musical drama that, at its best, hits some very high notes indeed.
A heavenly musical filled with down-to-earth humour.
La La Land is a monster musical, embracing every cliche about the hopes and frustrations of young talent in Hollywood as if they were all newly minted.
It has its head in the stars, and for a little over two wonderstruck hours, it lifts you up there too.

Most cinema-goers are already madly in love with at least one of them, and that love will hit stratospheric new heights when they see how skilfully Gosling and Stone balance their absurd attractiveness with goofy self-deprecation in La La Land.
Breaking into song and dance can be both deadly serious and a whole lot of fun.
La La Land serves to remind us that movies can still be magical, and they can still provide the channel for us to see magic in the world around us.
If you haven't succumbed to the joyous magic of La La Land by the end of the Fred-and-Ginger-flavored "A Lovely Night," well, then, pick up your Official Curmudgeon badge and head for the exit.
A gorgeous homage to the golden age of Hollywood musicals in the 1950s, the film has the power to make audiences laugh, weep and feel as if they can float on air.
A fabulous old-school Hollywood musical in modern-day Tinseltown with joyous tunes, exceptional choreography, a feel-good love story and a hint of bittersweetness to keep all that wonder grounded.

La La does nothing less than jolt the movie musical to life for the 21st century. You leave exhilarated by Damien Chazelle's nonstop inventiveness, dazzled by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, and thrilled how they made movies magic again.
Both old-fashioned and contemporary, the movie understands and celebrates what makes musicals tick. People sing because they feel so much. Emotions have to come out.
"La La Land" deserves credit for high spirits even if it's essentially a collection of glamorous throwback music videos for so-so songs.

There's more to a Hollywood musical than the musical. There's fantasy. There's magic. There's a genre which isn't afraid to recreate what romance actually feels like. And that's where "La La Land" soars.
It's more vibrant than Chicago, more heartfelt than Les Miserables, and more successfully staged than a chorus of other contenders.
Long live the musical. Bring enough Kleenex.
As a candy-hued musical valentine to Los Angeles, "La La Land" is both a crowd-pleaser and a locals-only inside joke.
Romantic, inventive, visually dazzling - and yet, Damien Chazelle's ambitious movie promises slightly more than it delivers.
That not every note or dance step is perfect isn't the point; it's that the actors find perfection - and magic - in the moment, in that flight.

We don't generally think of musicals in these terms, but, following the impersonal splashiness of the opening number, "La La Land" slowly dawns as a film of great intimacy. It's as if it were whispering to us.
If you have friends who say they don't make good movies anymore, drag them to this.
The movie comes off as a well-intended tribute to the fabulous MGM musicals of the great Vincente Minnelli, made by people who have never seen one.
This is one crowd-pleaser worth getting behind.
It's simply wonderful.

Working together for the third time, Stone and Gosling quickly establish an easy rapport with one another, their surpassingly attractive physical features the perfect foils for Chazelle's aesthetic approach of naturalism and extreme stylization.
Chazelle is a born filmmaker, and he doesn't settle for rehashing familiar bits from musicals we already love. He's too busy giving us reasons to fall for this one.
At a time when musicals seldom grace the big screen, "La La Land" is practically a miracle.
During one musical number, when fireworks start going off in the sky, you can feel them going off in your head too.

It's a film for those who feel a little out of step with the 21st century, as Mia does with her love of classic cinema and Sebastian does with his angry jazz certainty. A lot of us can relate. If you can't, we don't really want to hear about it.
I have yet to meet someone who's watched it and come out in a bad mood.
People say the movie musical is dead. Tell that that to your tapping toes while watching the enchantment of La La Land, one of the year's best films.
Almost anyone who happens to see it will be converted by minute three. Guaranteed.
I don't know if the music will still be sung in 20 or 30 years. I do know that dance schools all around the world are going to see a rush of enrolments.
If you haven't already fallen for this gauzy romp through the city of Angels at this point, you surely will during the last scene, with its bittersweet homage to the way times goes by.
Open-hearted gushy romanticism in CinemaScope. What's not to love?
If it were any more enchanting, the musical romantic comedy La La Land ... would break your heart.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: While ultimately an action-adventure, Black Panther also serves as an intelligent if broad debate between revolutionary rhetoric and the responsibilities of leadership.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Black Panther is every bit as good as you were hoping. Actually -- it's better. A terrific screenplay from Ryan Coogler and Joe Robert Cole elevates this thing way beyond the usual boundaries of the Marvel Universe.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: You can see [Michael B.] Jordan offhandedly weighing the line in his mind like a rock he's about to lob: it's one of many nicely judged moments of performance here from a wildly appealing ensemble cast without a weak link.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: The director Ryan Coogler and a charismatic cast... turn racial clich√©s on their head and drag in some heavy Shakespearean conflict to create a vivid yarn that's entirely new, frequently startling and, at every step along the way, all Marvel.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: The Black Panther is not only one of the most entertaining recent superhero films but has an intelligence and a political dimension that such inchoate offerings as Suicide Squad and Justice League completely lacked.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: While the themes are deep, Black Panther is at the same time a visual joy to behold, with confident quirkiness, insane action sequences and special effects, and the glorious reveal of Wakanda,

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Coogler has taken every genre in which black characters are traditionally sidelined, and then, with considerable flair and boldness, he's combined those genres and put black characters right at their heart.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: The intriguing thing about Black Panther is that it doesn't look like a superhero film - more a wide-eyed fantasy romance: exciting, subversive and funny.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Say this about Black Panther, which raises movie escapism very near the level of art: You've never seen anything like it in your life.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Crashingly enjoyable, frequently exciting and even, when it wants, borderline witty.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: ... it's a very rich buffet - geopolitical thriller, futuristic fantasy, coming-of-age story, African adventure with mystical overtones... it offers a wide variety of tastes and sensations but they never really come together to form a satisfying whole.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Rarely has a superhero origin story been as satisfying as Black Panther, which in many ways doesn't feel like a typical Marvel movie - and more power to that.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: "Black Panther" matters.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Exactly the kind of risk Marvel should be taking with every film they make.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: It is a terrifically entertaining film, alive from the start, following its Marvel mission (for good and bad) while rising above it.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: This is 2018's first great motion picture - a title that will surely be remembered when "end of the year" bests are discussed.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Black Panther is one of the best superhero movies of the century.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: To the infinite credit of Coogler and his team, Black Panther fights constantly and bitterly against the familiar constraints of Disney's superhero industrial complex.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: It's very, very good -- in its best scenes, exhilarating.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: May Marvel learn its lesson from "Black Panther": When a movie like this ends up feeling both personal and vital, you've done something right.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Chadwick Boseman commands every moment of this film, radiating probity and purpose, and it's only later on that you realize that, with another actor, this wouldn't have been a sure thing.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Coogler is a young filmmaker - this is just his third feature, following "Fruitvale Station" and "Creed" (two fine and very different films) - but he marshals this world with confidence and flair.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Like all the best comics movies, this one's got a villain (Michael B. Jordan) so compelling he nearly steals the show from the hero (Chadwick Boseman).

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Coogler builds a thrilling, exciting world, and threads throughout it a story filled with pathos and real-world gravitas.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: ... a film that fulfills the most rote demands of superhero spectacle, yet does so with style and subtexts that feel bracingly, joyfully groundbreaking.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Ryan Coogler has eschewed the familiar Marvel glut of smug in-jokes and mind-numbing CGI explosions to create a visually dazzling work of art.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: For all their global dominance, everybody wants these superhero movies to be better: funnier, smarter, more inclusive, more super. A huge step in the right direction, Black Panther is that dream come true.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Visually, "Black Panther" is often spectacular...It's warriors with spears and force-field shields. It's aircraft that soar and swoop like birds over the Serengeti. It's "Blade Runner" in Dar es Salaam instead of L.A.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: It's uniquely satisfying popcorn entertainment, a triumphant trifecta of subject matter, talent and timing.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: One of the year's best films, and one that transcends the superhero genre to emerge as an epic of operatic proportions.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Believe the hype: "Black Panther" transcends its comic-book origins, achieving a mythic grandeur that's nothing short of exhilarating.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: The richness of the visual palette here is dazzling.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: If it isn't indisputably the best of Marvel's 18 offerings, it is certainly a contender.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Ultimately, it's more interesting to think about than it is to watch.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: When it comes to creative visuals, engaging action and likable characters, "Black Panther" stands confidently next to the best fare offered up by the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
It is tremendously buoyant and watchable, with some great visual invention.
Pixar's most ambitious, imaginative and adult film takes a look at the emotions that control our wellbeing.
[Inside Out] can easily stand alongside Pixar's greatest films.
Inside Out is delightfully inventive, funny and touching and, surreptitiously, a great way of helping kids get a handle on all those inexplicable feelings.
It's a totally satisfying adventure with lot of surprising twists, and one of the best emotional payoffs in the Pixar canon.
A great blend of thoughtfulness and understanding went into "Inside Out," and the outcome will likely, again, raise the bar for other studios trying to keep up.
Only Pixar could turn a metaphor into a heart-tugging story about preteen growing pains. Absolutely brilliant.

Pixar's tour of an 11-year-old girl's head is a flat-out masterpiece that proves live action doesn't have dibs on cinematic art. Oh, did I say it was funny? It is, uproariously so, when you're not brushing away a tear.
In the course of the whole year, there will probably be no American movie so concerned with looking inside, and so interested in the components of a meaningful life, as "Inside Out."
Perhaps Pixar will never again reach the heights of its remarkable string of masterworks, "Wall.E," "Ratatouille" and "Up." The best of "Inside Out" comes close.
It is a joy for audiences seeking entertainment, an ingenious work of craft for those paying close attention, and a wallop of feeling that's still too rare coming from a cartoon.

You want to see this movie. You need to see this movie. Because "Inside Out" is terrific, a mind-bending concept turned into a brilliant film, a return to form for Pixar not just in terms of quality but in taking risks - risks that pay off.
Whatever brainstorm led the Pixar folks to "Inside Out," they've created the most extraordinary film of the year.

Inside Out is imaginative and ambitious, even if it sometimes feels a bit manically overstuffed. And it's definitely a big step up from some recent Pixar films, such as Cars 2 and Monsters University.

At times, you ache to put the brakes on the chaos, but still Pixar manages to do what it does best, turning the everyday rough and smooth of childhood experience into a thoughtful, inventive adventure.
Not since Up, has the studio taken on the gnarliness of being human and made it so visually delightful and emotionally resonant.
It's good to get your emotions in check before watching the exquisite Inside Out. You're bound to feel the whole bunch watching a child's mind come alive in the most imaginative ways.
It's not unusual for a film about childhood loss to be this funny while it sets about the work of making you cry; it is unusual for it to be this much fun.
The best animated movies are made as much for the grown-ups who will accompany the children as for the kids themselves. That's certainly true of "Inside Out" ...
Inside Out, the latest Disney-Pixar coproduction, feels like a clever educational short stretched to feature length.
Kids will be engaged, but it's the older viewers - people who have lived and felt a little longer than 11-year-olds - who will most appreciate this marvelous, ingenious work of art.
The magnificent head trip that is Inside Out does more than take us inside a young girl's mind. It also restores Pixar's lost magic.

Uncle Walt knew what he was talking about with "For every smile, a tear." With "Inside Out," the brilliant keepers of his legacy prove that it's not only good for business but also essential for the soul.
The preoccupation with the sorts of problems that young girls really do encounter makes it brave, as well as beautiful.

Directors Pete Docter ( Monsters, Inc .; Up) and Ronnie del Carmen ( Dug's Special Mission) have created a masterful study of family dynamics. Like the Oscar-winning Up, Inside Out takes great care in weaving complex ideas into a children's tale.

"Inside Out" is about the passing of childhood ritual, its most bittersweet moments the ones glimpsed in a rear-view mirror, as it reminds the unfaithful: Remember when you loved that? When you lived for this? Until you didn't anymore?
"Inside Out" movingly but casually plays with our emotions, like a baby walking her fingers across a parent's face; it leaves you changed, entertained, nostalgic, dazzled.

The kind of classic that lingers in the mind after you've seen it, sparking personal associations. And if it's as successful as I suspect it will be, it could shake American studio animation out of the doldrums it's been mired in for years.
Inside Out is the best American-produced animated film we have seen in many summers and deserves to be recognized as such.
Inside Out is the first psychological thriller that's fun for the whole family. Really psychological. And really fun.
This is a humane and heart-wrenchingly beautiful film from Docter; even measured alongside Pixar's numerous great pictures, it stands out as one of the studio's very best.
This is a movie that dares to explore existential crises, in the middle of the summer, in an animated movie that's aimed at the whole family
It is the universality of the film that makes it an instant classic. Inside Out combines simplicity with extraordinary formal daring and sophistication.

Tthe ordinary trauma of an 11-year-old girl coming to terms with a new life and school while losing all her old, comforting, childish certainties has become a glittering, bravura piece of cinema, a comedy both wise and tender.
Inside Out is animated cinema's brainstorm of the year, possibly the decade.
Inside Out [is] a bold, gorgeous, sweet, funny, sometimes heartbreakingly sad, candy-colored adventure that deserves an Academy Award nomination for best picture.
In the first half of the film, I was being piloted by Confusion and Dissatisfaction. But by the end, Joy was very much in charge.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: Stunningly moving and powerful: intimate, passionate, often shocking, and almost mesmerically absorbing.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: Heartbreaking [and] deeply sympathetic.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: There is an unutterable sadness at the heart of Asif Kapadia's brilliant new film about Amy Winehouse.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: If the film has a fault, it's that it doesn't try to explain where her genius came from. But then it's all there, in front of us.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: It's a perceptive examination of the singer's need for love -- from her friends, family, colleagues, husband and public -- and the ways in which that need went unmet, or was exploited, at the times it ached in her the most.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: The result may be depressing, but the performance footage balances it with rousing evidence of Winehouse's eternal talent.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: It's clear the smart, passionate singer knew her own mind - and the consequences of what she was doing to her body. But her tragic end, and the highly publicized chaos leading up to it, shows self-awareness wasn't enough.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: Anyone with a beating heart will be forgiven for allowing it to break during this unflinching and thoughtful account of the life and death of the soul singer.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: It is clear that Kapadia adores her, and wishes to honour her story by telling it without flinching.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: Like all theories, the doc's "truth vs. phoniness" narrative has a few blind spots.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: If only this film hadn't been so desperate to shoehorn in all the drama and had examined a more esoteric slice of her life, we might have come away with a more intimate portrait that merited such a familiar title.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: The speed of her fall now appears dizzying and terrible. Or was it rather the speed of her ascension?

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: A highly absorbing, sensitively told and ultimately devastating documentary directed by Asif Kapadia.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: Watching Amy is a torturous but endlessly hypnotic experience.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: The ugly unraveling of Winehouse's life infuriates and saddens anew, as Kapadia's poignant documentary reminds viewers of what was and what might have been, but was ultimately, tragically never to be.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: "Amy" makes you wonder about a lot of things, one being the oldest cliche in show business - the one about the high price of notoriety, whether you have the money to cover the bill or not.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: The film is often uncomfortable to watch, prompting that little voice inside each of us to scream out "Somebody help her!"

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: One thing is for certain: It will be much harder to hear that handful of powerful, lush, carnal songs on Back to Black without the wallop of melancholy.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: "Amy" doesn't depart from the standard behind-the-music template, but it does deepen the format immeasurably, through the intimacy of its archival materials and the focus of its approach.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: The film is remarkable not just for the immense talent there to see in Winehouse's performances, but the fact that there is so much to see.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: "Amy," Asif Kapadia's documentary about the short, tragic life of British retro soul singer Amy Winehouse, is a heartbreaker.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: Kapadia's illuminating, compassionate and tragic doc goes way up and way, way down with the gone-too-soon Amy Winehouse.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: A loving but honest portrayal of a doomed talent.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: To his credit, [director Asif] Kapadia allows the murk of recollected events to complicate matters, and everyone gets their say.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: It's hard to watch. And even harder to look away.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: In Kapadia's assured and careful hands, the film becomes less a portrait of a tragic artist, whose downward spiral was exacerbated by opportunistic family members and colleagues, than a discomfiting mirror held up to her audience.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: "Amy" is a film about the waste of a great talent, and you dread the inevitable ending.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: You don't need to be a fan of British singer Amy Winehouse to be moved by the documentary Amy, a devastating examination of the deadly effect that celebrity culture, media and drugs can have on artists.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: A mesmerizing yet devastating look at a singular talent.

genres: Art House & International, Documentary, Musical & Performing Arts, Special Interest
review_content: It's Amy's words, her music, her voicemails, her home videos, her friends, her family, her tormentors, and her timeless incandescence. Look, listen and weep.

A sweet, deeply personal portrayal of female adolescence that's more attuned to the bonds between best girlfriends than casual flings with boys, writer-director Greta Gerwig's beautiful Lady Bird flutters with the attractively loose rhythms of youth.
Lady Bird is a film bursting with warmth, wit and melancholy that manages to seem fresh and unexpected despite the overly stacked nature of the subgenre.
There are no fireworks or twists or unnecessary frills here, nor should there be - this is simply perfect filmmaking from a voice that demands to be heard.

Lady Bird is a perfect coming-of-age comedy for anyone who's ever had teenage wanderlust, fought with their parents, fostered a love-hate tension with their hometown or popped Communion wafers in secret.
One of the best films of the year. In telling her own coming of age story, Gerwig proves herself a blazing talent and Ronan and Metcalf should have Oscar calling. Totally irresistible.
One of the better solo directing debuts by an actor in recent memory.
A small, gentle charmer about what life's like for a teenager who knows she's far more interesting than the town she lives in.
Greta Gerwig is spreading her wings as a filmmaker - and she soars with "Lady Bird."

A finely wrought, deeply felt mash note to Gerwig's hometown of Sacramento, and the rare film about teenage life that puts equal weight on the dark, sad and tough parts, as it does on the joyous, raucous, euphoric moments.
It hit me unexpectedly-like a snowball between the eyes.

As an actor, Gerwig has shown an enchantingly light touch; she brings that to her work as director, as "Lady Bird" skims along happily, showing us moments both crucial and trivial in a teenage girl's life.
Lady Bird may sound slight, but it offers an eloquent, fresh voice from a thoroughly accomplished film-maker.
The delightful and insightful Lady Bird achieves flight in its own unique way, just like the aerodynamically unorthodox ladybug the title tips to.
Lady Bird is a coming-of-age story distinguished by a great script and a perfect cast.

Highlighted by an awards-worthy performance by Saoirse Ronan and structured around a light, witty script by Gerwig, the movie delivers a well-targeted snapshot of a year-in-the-life of an ordinary high school senior.
It's unique and original and fresh and wonderful, and can you tell I loved it?
It's a great movie.
In Ronan's marvelous performance, tough and transparent at the same time, we can see the blurred outlines of the equally assured filmmaker behind her.
"Lady Bird" is a triumph of style, sensibility and spirit. The girl at its center may not be a heavyweight, but her movie is epic.
I love it. If a more enchanted movie comes along this year, I'll be surprised.
This is simply beautiful work.
Lots of movies are set to be popping up in multiplexes, but few as wonderful as "Lady Bird."
One of the best movies about adolescence to come along in years.
Writer-director Gerwig manages brilliantly the delicate feat of portraying the vulnerabilities and eccentricities of the townsfolk without patronising them.
Almost everything here bespeaks Gerwig, including the cast's tendency to act one line or dramatic moment with breezy brio, as if already on the run to the next. Very GG.
A gloriously funny and wistfully autobiographical coming-of-age comedy.
If Gerwig is capable of all this in her first solo feature, who knows what feats of woodwork she'll craft for us next.

As teen movies go, it's supremely sophisticated, capturing and crystallising that moment in adolescence when it seems that life is at last about to start and the only place you want to be is elsewhere.
Like many wonderful actresses with a gift for words (think Julie Delpy, Sarah Polley and Lake Bell) Gerwig has slipped behind the camera to create something quietly political.
Gerwig's deft handling of script, camera and actors is all the more impressive given that this is her first film as solo director.
It's two hours long but feels like an eternity, lurching incoherently from one noisy set-piece to another.
Violence and vulgarity replace the humor and poetry of Guillermo del Toro's superhero films.

Marshall and screenwriter Andrew Cosby went overboard with their R-rating, introducing so much gore and profanity that it, quite frankly, gets dull. The flat performances and incoherent story do not help matters.
It's really a series of violent vignettes strung together, getting more and more outlandish and introducing characters at such a blistering pace that you just want it to stop already.
"Hellboy" plays out as a non-interactive video game. It would be a lot more fun if you were the one swinging a virtual sword and making body parts fly. Assuming you're into that sort of thing.
The race for worst movie of the year is heating up. You could even say it's hotter than hell, now that "Hellboy" has taken the lead.

"Hellboy" is kind of all over the place, with two hours' worth of adventures (and misadventures) that never gel cohesively and momentum-killing flashback origin stories for pretty much every main character.

Marshall doles out not just cartoonish gore but a microwaved stew of Arthurian hokum, mystic fish and chip shops, ill-fated London landmarks and secret societies of blueblood occultists in smoking jackets.

The chief battle here isn't the one on screen between Hellboy and a sixth century witch; it's between Harbour and the uninspired gore and bland rock music in which his unfortunate first starring vehicle is soaked.

It's in tune with the current public taste for over-the-top horror. But it seems pointless regardless, as does the CGI overkill that turns every battle into a bloodbath leaving mutilated and decapitated bodies.
The new Hellboy lands with a thud that's loud and dark - but almost instantly forgettable.
A decade on, this largely routine reboot from British director Neil Marshall...is no compensation for whatever we missed out on back then.
British director Neil Marshall's reboot of the Hellboy franchise is a lurid, confusing mess, only partially redeemed by its tongue-in-cheek humour and fitfully impressive visual effects.
Comparing it to Del Toro's 2004 original and 2008 sequel is like making an analogy between a Broadway production and a high school stage show.
You will never realize how much you need Guillermo del Toro in your life until you see the reboot of Hellboy.
Ugly, obnoxious and yowlingly witless, with nothing to say for itself that doesn't start with the letter F.
At two hours, "Hellboy" feels closer to three. And yet there still seems to be something missing.

For all the badass attitude and the CGI mini-apocalypses he strides through, this Hellboy is lacking. He is more of a Heckboy: a banal action-movie figure without the unexpected likability of his previous iteration.
Watching Hellboy is my new personal idea of hell.
This is the Vitamix school of film-making. Cram everything into the blender, add gore and press "whizz".
In the end, the movie leaves us stuck with unmoving drama and increasingly numbing carnage, delivered with a hand as heavy as Hellboy's monstrously oversized right meathook.
Watching the "Hellboy" reboot is like eating a rice cake - you don't feel bad afterward, but at the same time you're not entirely sure you really experienced anything at all.
This all hurtles at a relentless, unforgiving pace, glued together with many, many crunchy guitar licks. You don't so much as watch this movie as submit to being pummeled by it.
If it was my call, I'd write nothing about the movie and leave this space blank for readers' notes.
It ends up simply being a franchise reboot damned to be restaged as its own bloody hell. Some things are better left dead.

It's a splendid-looking film. The effects are striking throughout, whether they are dramatic battle confrontations between humans and the forces of the natural world, or small moments of delicate detail.
Think twice about taking very young children - or even some susceptible adults - to this at-times shocking, if less than graphic, gloom-and-doom fest. But the worse sin is: It's boring.
The cuddly creatures and razzle-dazzle action are enough to make two hours disappear, but it's only Jolie's bat-winged charisma that will rattle on in your memory.
As the nemesis to Angelina Jolie's red-lipped siren, Pfeiffer gives us exactly what we want -- the same hissing Catwoman attitude she heated up for Mother!
Until then, though, Maleficent: Mistress of Evil swoops you along with ease. Like so many Disney films, it is a commercial calculation with a just a splash of magic.
While the first film was, like "Wicked," an alternate view of a classic good-versus-evil tale, its sequel is a one-note, moralistic sledgehammer with no payoff.
Maleficent may have offered a sharp, original take on a well-worn story, but its sequel just feels like more fantasy fluff.
Jolie's magnetism, + the way she toes the line between being a fairy version of Batman and a menacing mistress of not-quite-evil-but-pretty-close, is why these "Maleficent" movies work.
R√∏nning, who served his Hollywood apprenticeship on the fifth Pirates of the Caribbean film, seems to be enslaving himself to franchises which dictate the most anonymous job possible.
This Maleficent is disappointing, although Jolie certainly sells it hard, as does Fanning, who takes it as seriously as anything else in her career.
Mistress of Evil makes a conscious decision to address a subject that not many family films would touch with a ten-foot pole...then bungles the implications and the message.
References to real-world tragedy can be worthwhile... But here, these plot elements come across as random, misguided and sadly unimaginative.
The saddest thing about "Maleficent: Mistress of Evil" is that it's not bad, but typical, that this emptiness - this immersion in mass numbification - is the modern style.
The messages that undergird "Maleficent: Mistress of Evil" are important ones. If only they didn't come wrapped in this goofy, chaotic package.
What the story boils down to, then, is a mixed-marriage parable, one that could be panderingly "on trend," but which the filmmakers handle fairly thoughtfully.
Maleficent: Mistress of Evil is a misfire, despite its wonderful title, which feels plucked straight from an Elvira movie.
Jolie, of course, is compelling, charismatic, underused and far too good for the material.
In this melted, wannabe 'Frozen', Angelina Jolie and her cheekbones return to an inert franchise to glare at Michelle Pfeiffer.

Jolie seems utterly trapped by the narrow conception of the role, which requires her to speak in a clipped British accent and keep emotional display to a minimum. Sometimes her stiffness is played for laughs, sometimes she's just stiff.
It all feels rushed-through and improperly considered, like a fairy tale told to a child by a grownup who's tired and bored and just wants to go to bed.
It's not just that Jolie's character is more captivating and engrossing than pretty much anything else in the movie, it's that her clothes are too.
Really, the fun of this movie - aside from the glorious and very velvet-forward costumes, by Ellen Mirojnick - is the performances of the two Hollywood pros at its center, both perfectly cast.
The bottom line is that Maleficent 2 takes a brilliant character and doesn't completely bugger things up.
And [Jolie] is a star here: something amazing to behold, an Old Hollywood glamour shot come to...well, not exactly come to life, but mobile, anyway.
Sadly, such fun is not to be had in "Mistress of Evil," a needless sequel to the 2014 "Sleeping Beauty" riff that fails to fully value the entire of appeal of these films: Jolie's Maleficent.

We get a classic buildup establishing heroes and villains; gorgeous, screen-popping visuals featuring beautiful and mysterious worlds; a bounty of colorful and magical creatures, and a lengthy, CGI-laden, climactic battle sequence...
Fans of the stage musical may swoon, but others will be severely allergic.
This all-star, all-awful screen take on the smash Broadway musical easily scores as the worst movie of the year and arguably the decade. Cats shouldn't happen to a dog.
"Cats" turns the most vacuous stage musical of the 1980s into a big-screen litter box for the hammiest of stars to unload into.
I enjoyed the film for what it is. It's London's Got Talent for the feline set.
I realize "It's not that bad!" won't be used in the Cats advertising campaign, but it is worth noting that the peculiar musical does indeed have merit.
I felt the light inside me slowly fading.
I never thought I would say "There's something for everyone." But really there is in this film.
I found "Cats" pretty bland, but it has its moments of catnip, and as a holiday movie option that anyone could see, it might be just the ticket.

By the final scene, by which my eyebrows were hurting from being raised so high (the winning cat goes to the Heavyside Layer in a chandelier? What is this, "Phantom of the Opera"?), I was just tired. As was "Cats." Meow.
Cats may flop but it will be found by a likeminded audience, maybe the same one that rescued The Greatest Showman. Don't be the sourpuss to tell these people they're wrong.
Oh God, my eyes.
Cats isn't the cat-astrophe that everyone either feared or hoped for back in July, but it isn't a triumphant vindication of Hooper's vision, either.
It all just feels so wrong.
A bunch of well-known celebrities get turned into singing, scenery-chewing digital kitties in the utterly absurd yet oddly charming movie musical version of the Broadway hit.
Finding any high point in Cats, though, takes some serious scratching.
Hooper is not my man for film musicals.
I didn't hate it.
Director Tom Hooper's movie is a huge failure because he's completely abandoned the fundamentals of what made "Cats" a terrific show.
Of the thought, of the thought, of what on earth to do now. "Pretend to be cats!" says a director. They reply ... "Me? How?"
If you have no prior familiarity with the wordy, purring absurdism of "Cats," it'll just hit harder, and you'll likely have a lot of questions.
There isn't much more to Cats than the experience of sitting back and watching weird-looking performers pretending to be cats while gyrating to Andrew Lloyd Webber songs.
It's deliberate doggerel. It's nonsense rhymes. And, for a movie audience accustomed to traits and arcs upon which they can hang their interest, it's deeply boring.
It's one of those rare cinematic events that feels like a collective hallucination - improbable and entirely indescribable.

The worst thing about Cats - and I was forced to see two cat burglars sensually drape a string of pearls around the scruff of Hayward in the obvious foray to a cat threesome - is that it was made in the first place.
As the trailer suggested, the enduring stage musical is a bad fit for the big screen.
While it's far from being perfect, or even purr-fect, it certainly doesn't warrant the abuse that has been heaped upon it. At the very least, it deserves a chance.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: "Venom"? More like cyanide.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Venom is a mess of a movie, a baffling mishmash of sci-fi, horror and comedy elements and one which squanders most of the resources at its disposal.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Even the great Tom Hardy is defeated by this tone-deaf Marvel botch job, which delivers a puddle of simplistic, sanitized PG-13 drivel instead of the scary, dark-night-of-the-soul thunderbolt fans had every right to expect..

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Venom is obviously the victim of some brutal editing, and the derivative, sketchily plotted B-movie that's left is as scrappy and hurried as a trailer.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Nowhere near as edgy or exciting as it should have been.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Why can't the movie make Venom properly dirty? The PG-13 rating seriously hurts.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Riz Ahmed's evil mad scientist starts well but, like Hardy, is swallowed up by mayhem and metamorphosis. By the hour mark, matters have become seriously boring.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: It's a mess, but wow, is it ever a fun, fascinating mess.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Sony Pictures appear to have lavished a nine-figure sum on, and are now hoping to establish an entire cinematic universe on the back of, a character who looks like someone drizzled Creme Egg filling onto a bin bag.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Venom is riddled with the poison of dullness.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Part of the reason the superhero genre has managed to elevate itself is it gives us characters that we root for and care about. Venom does none of this.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: At some future gala event where Tom Hardy is being feted for his incredible acting career, the clip from Venom will be the one that gets the audience laughing.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: It all ends with a gaudy computer-generated eye-gasm and the sense that you might just have seen the worst comic-book blockbuster of the decade.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: It's just not an especially good superhero movie and it wastes an intriguing premise.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: It's an incoherent mess of tones, acting styles and visual effects. And yet it's kind of a hoot.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: A picture in the running for the dubious distinction of being perhaps the worst Marvel-derived origin story ever. And that includes the odious 2015 "Fantastic Four."

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: There's nothing memorable in "Venom," nothing to talk about the next day. But if it happens to hit you right, its lightness is refreshing.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: A tonally wonky lark that's actually stronger when it's sillier. It's a mess, but a fun mess-at least for a while.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: A tone-deaf, uneven and maddeningly dumb clunker that never settles on an identity, all the way to the closing credits.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: The Venom symbiote requires a perfect match to bond with its host; otherwise, the host is doomed. The Venom movie plays like a midnight horror that has invaded a superhero movie, and while there are some laffs to be had, it's far from a perfect match.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Certainly I'm in a minority when it comes to my fellow critics, but I liked "Venom." Hell, if it wasn't for the sloppy and formulaic script, I might have even loved it.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: "Venom" could become Marvel's version of "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" or "Santa Claus Conquers the Martians" -- a camp classic worth mocking again and again.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: The chief problem with "Venom" is that it never settles on a tone. Is it comedy? Horror? Romance? Drama? Why not try all of them at once?

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: A horribly scripted film so bad as to be enjoyable, but not bad enough to be good.

genres: Action & Adventure, Drama, Science Fiction & Fantasy
review_content: Sony, overly intent on empire-building, has jettisoned a crucial ingredient: bite.
How meh is The Mummy? Let me count the ways. For all the digital desperation from overworked computers, this Tom Cruise reboot lands onscreen with a resounding thud. Epic fail.

Falls apart at the end, rattling its bones through a series of shockingly violent clashes with Ahmanet. Ultimately, despite her awesome powers, this goddess is reduced to participating in a love triangle with mere mortals. How pedestrian.

Universal is counting on "The Mummy" and its successors to make it a competitor with Disney/Marvel and Warner Bros./DC and their ever-expanding world of comic-book-based characters. Guys, you might want to have a backup plan.
This movie's a mess.
This latest remake or reboot (does anyone truly know the difference?) feels less alive than undead.
Begins entertainingly before miring itself in dialogue-light CGI pyrotechnics.
Whenever the action stops, though, the film becomes derivative and empty headed, Strip away the bandages and there really isn't very much here at all.
A tomb full of action-packed guilty pleasure that owns its horror, humor and rampant silliness equally.
It's a ragbag of action scenes which needed to be bandaged more tightly.
Unlike the old movies that supposedly inspired it, "The Mummy" has no atmosphere, no menace, no romance.
Universal's monster franchise has made it out of the tomb, just about - but if this rebirth is going to sustain itself long term, it's going to need a little more meat under its bandages.
Narratively incoherent and full of cheese and camp, this movie makes it clear that the mummy should have remained dead and buried.
[The Mummy] begins with B-movie fun, but descends into an impenetrable soup of battling pixels.
Did our hero even bother to read the script for this toxic CGI dump site?
The big thrills and few laughs are no match for the cumbersome, convoluted story, not to mention the nonexistent chemistry between Cruise and Wallis.
Nothing quite comes together in this crazy mix of action, jokes, ancient curses and the undead, and even Tom Cruise's star power can't glue the thing together.
There are a few amusing lines and creepy moments, but, between the headache-inducing flashbacks and hallucinations, the narrative would be easier to follow if it were written in hieroglyphics.
Sometimes it takes a disaster of this magnitude to leave us hoping a studio will take a long hard look at the universe they're about to expand.
"The Mummy" is the rare Cruise film that doesn't quite give audiences their money's worth.
It's amazingly relentless in its naked borrowing from other, better horror and sci-fi movies.
The film might have been silly enough to be enjoyably camp. Instead it's a witless omnium gatherum of mongrel sources and clich√©s.
The movie is a pain in the sarcophagus. I fear that it will anger the gods.
It plays, in fact, like a movie directed by a producer, someone checking items off a to-do list rather than telling a story in a consistent tone.
You only have to watch the trailer to know that Producer-Director Alex Kurtzman's reboot of Brendan Fraser's once-charming mummy movies is full of embalming fluid.

I was curious enough about Universal's decision to exhume its classic monsters to hold on until the zombie crusader frogmen started swimming after amoral (but maybe-redeemable) soldier of fortune Tom Cruise. No one would blame you for checking out sooner.

The movie itself is rather like the Hollywood mummies of old: There it walks, lurching from side to side on rigid legs, deadly in its intent but uncertain of the right path, trailing bandages as it goes.
Stunningly bad.
It feels less like a movie than a series of compromises worked out by a corporate committee.
